Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: AC-MWN: A Novel Architecture for Application-Aware Cognitive Multihop Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Given the recent upward trend in wireless traffic, capacity demand increases faster than spectral efficiency and availability. However, it has been well-known that in wireless communications, some of the spectra are significantly under-utilized. This fact has attracted researchers from academia and industry who are interested in the next generation of cognitive radio communication systems. Despite the tremendous ongoing efforts on this research topic, there is a huge gap between the research on cognitive radios and the network applications. This project exploits a novel wireless networking paradigm called Application-Aware Cognitive Multihop Wireless Networks (AC-MWN). This architecture includes a mega network layer for multihop wireless networks, which combines the major functionalities of medium access control, network and transport layers in the traditional layered model of wireless networks. The mega network layer has cognition to the spectrum availability and to the requirements of the network applications. Additionally, the new design can efficiently utilize the spectrum resources and effectively adjust the application resources, such as storage and computational capabilities. While AC-MWN accommodates the requirements of different network applications, it also can drive the capacity closer to the upper theoretical limit for MWNs. Therefore, this architecture satisfies the requirements of application-aware cognitive multihop wireless networks. The AC-MWN research effort will have a significant impact on the better understanding of the designs for future cognitive multihop wireless networks and provide improvements for many application domains, including public safety, disaster rescues, environmental monitoring, and medical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated a new wireless networking paradigm called Application-Aware Cognitive Multihop Wireless Networks (AC-MWN). The architecture includes a mega network layer for multihop wireless networks, which combines the major functionalities of medium access control, network and transport layers in the traditional layered model of wireless networks. The proposed mega network layer have cognitions on both the spectrum availability in the network and the requirements of applications of the network. Moreover, the new architecture not only can efficiently utilize the spectrum resources, but also can effectively adjust the application resources, such as storage and computational capabilities, etc. AC-MWN can push the capacity limit for MWNs and at the same time to accommodate the requirements of different applications in MWNs, thus achieving application-aware cognitive multihop wireless network design.

During the four years of the project, the project team exploreed two of the most challenging requirements for design and deployment of multihop wireless networks, enhancing network capacity and accommodating application requirements, by providing detailed mega network layer protocol and algorithm design, and then studying the AC-MWN theoretical limits and performance tradeoffs. Specifically, various sesearch activities were conducted:

-   A backbone construction scheme for multi-hop wireless cognitive radio networks with a channel bonding technique

-   A network coding aware channel allocation and routing scheme for multi-hop cognitive radio networks

-   A joint channel allocation and multicast routing scheme for a multi-hop cognitive radio network

-   Delay-based channel allocation in multi-hop cognitive radio networks

-   Study on energy efficient communications in multi-hop cognitive radio networks

-   Adaptive channel allocation and routing in cognitive radio networks

-   A game theoretic approach for energy efficient communications in multi-hop cognitive radio networks

-   Application-aware routing for multi-hop cognitive radio networks with channel bonding

-   A cross-layer study for application-aware multi-hop cognitive radio networks

Computer simulations and a prototype testbed were developed to evaluate the performance and tradeoffs and validate the theoretical results for AC-MWN. As part of the comprehensive study, theoretical results to achieve optimal performance for AC-MWN, as well as practical engineering design rules and guidelines for implementation and deployment of AC-MWN, were obtained in the series od studies above.

The AC-MWN research activities have significantly advanced the understanding in the field of multi-hop wireless networks, which plays a key role in the modern society. The research efforts associated with the AC-MWN project have a significant impact on the design of future multihop wireless networks, including wireless mesh networks, wireless sensor networks, mobile ad-hoc networks and vehicular ad-hoc networks, which can improve many application domains, including public safety, disaster rescues, environmental monitoring and medical applications. The outcome of the project will foster the transition of our society into the pervasive computing age, where the network infrastructure shall support not only traditional communication patterns (i.e., human-to-human, human-to-computer and computer-to-computer) but also the communication needs from devices such as mobile phones, PDAs, sensors and RFID devices prevalent in daily life.
